raw_text:
Palestinian economy in decline
 
 Despite a short-lived increase in Palestinian jobs in 2003, the economy is performing well below its potential, said a World Bank report.
 
 Unemployment stood at 25%, compared with 10% before the uprising against Israeli occupation four years ago. Young people are particularly hard hit with 37% out of work, compared with 14% four years ago. But 104,000 new jobs were created last year during a brief easing of violence and closures. However, during the first half of this year, the Palestinian economy lost more than 22,000 jobs. Last year's growth rate of 6% can also be attributed to this temporary gap in violence, the report said. According to the report, Intifada, Closures and Palestinian Economic Crisis: An Assessment, there is a close link between the number of closures - both border closures and internal closures between cities - and Palestinian economic problems. The closures arranged by Israel restrict the movement of Palestinian people and goods, slowing down trade.
 
 "Closures are a key factor behind today's economic crisis in the West Bank," said Nigel Roberts, World Bank country director for the West Bank and Gaza. Nearly half of all Palestinians - some 47% - live below the poverty line and are particularly vulnerable to economic shocks. The report said even more would be on the poverty line without an average of $950m a year from international donors, some of which goes towards job creation. It also called on the Palestinian Authority to revive its reform programme and maintain financial discipline to create an investment-friendly climate. This week Colin Powell, US Secretary of State was visiting the West Bank to stress US support for a smooth Palestinian election in January.
llama3.2:1b: The Palestinian economy is performing below its potential due to high unemployment, particularly among young people (37% vs 14% four years ago). Job creation has been slow, with over 22,000 jobs lost during the first half of this year. The closures by Israel are a key factor in the economic crisis, restricting trade and movement of Palestinian people and goods. Nearly half of Palestinians live below the poverty line (47%), and international donors must provide $950m per year to support job creation and maintain financial discipline.
llama3.2:3b: The Palestinian economy is performing below potential with 25% unemployment and nearly half living below the poverty line. The economy benefited from a temporary decrease in violence, resulting in 104,000 new jobs last year, but lost over 22,000 jobs during the first half of this year. Closures imposed by Israel are a key factor behind economic problems.
gemma2:2b: The Palestinian economy is performing poorly below potential, with high unemployment rates and significant economic losses during the first half of 2023.  Closures by Israel have hampered trade and contributed to job losses. The World Bank report emphasizes the need for reform, financial discipline, and investment-friendly conditions in Palestine to improve its economy.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Despite a short-lived increase in jobs, the economy is performing well below potential in Palestine, according to a World Bank report. Palestinians are particularly vulnerable due to closures imposed by Israel, which restricts trade and employment. The closure of borders between cities has also led to job losses, with a 22% job loss rate during the first half of this year. The Palestinian economy is linked to closures both in border and internal areas. Colin Powell visited Palestine on Wednesday to stress US support for a January election.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Palestinian economy has been struggling since the start of the Intifada due to persistent violence, closures, unemployment rates reaching 25%, and difficulties in trade. The situation worsened last year with an increase in job losses, but economic growth was partly attributed to temporary easing of violence. Closure restrictions have a significant impact on the Palestinian economy, affecting nearly half of Palestinians living below the poverty line.
qwen2.5:3b: Palestinian economy in decline despite a brief increase in jobs in 2003. Unemployment stands at 25%, up from 10% before uprising; young people are hardest hit (37%). Last year, 104,000 new jobs were created but this year, more than 22,000 were lost due to increased violence and closures. Closures restrict movement and goods affecting trade. Nearly half of Palestinians live below poverty line, vulnerable to shocks; requires international donor aid for job creation. The World Bank recommends reviving reform programme and maintaining financial discipline. US supports smooth Palestinian election in January.

Palestinian economy in decline

"In this crisis in the West Bank, " said Nigel Roberts, World Bank country director for the West Bank and Gaza. Nearly half of all Palestinians live below the poverty line and are particularly vulnerable to economic shocks. According to the report, the report said even more would be on the poverty line without an average of $950m a year from international donors, which include donations towards job creation.
Palestine authorities also called on the Palestinian Authority to revive its reform programme and maintain financial discipline to create an investment-friendly climate. It further stressed that if this crisis continues, we must adopt a balanced approach by reducing taxes and increasing education.
smollm:1.7b: The Palestinian economy is performing well below its potential due to various factors, including high unemployment rates, particularly among young people. The economy has also been negatively impacted by closures and internal closures between cities, which restrict the movement of Palestinian people and goods, slowing down trade. Additionally, the Israeli blockade on Gaza has further exacerbated economic difficulties in the region. Despite some positive developments, such as a short-lived increase in Palestinian jobs in 2003, the overall economy is still struggling to recover from the devastating effects of the Intifada and closures. The report highlights the need for international support to revitalize the Palestinian economy and create an investment-friendly climate.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about the Palestinian economy's decline. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence says that despite a short-lived increase in jobs back in 2003, the economy hasn't improved much. The World Bank report mentions unemployment at 25%, compared to 10% four years ago. That means people aren't doing as well anymore.

Unemployment is particularly high among young people—37% out of work versus 14% before. But there were some new jobs created last year, about 6% growth. However, during the first half of this year, economic losses were 22,000 jobs lost. So, it's not a sustained problem.

The report also mentions closures by Israel—both border and internal—causing economic issues because it restricts movement, slowing trade. They call these closures "a key factor behind today's economic crisis."

Nigel Roberts from the World Bank says half of all Palestinians live below the poverty line, particularly vulnerable to shocks. Even without $950m per year from donors, more might need that to be sustainable.

The report emphasizes the Palestinian Authority needs reform and financial discipline. Also, Colin Powell is visiting to stress US support for a peaceful election in January.

So, putting this all together into a concise summary. I should mention the decrease in jobs, high unemployment among young people, some job creation, economic losses, closures causing issues, poverty challenges, need for reform, and the external support from the US.
</think>

The Palestinian economy has seen a slowdown since 2003, despite a rise in jobs that peaked in 2003. Unemployment has risen to 25%, compared to 10% four years earlier, with significant unemployment among young people at 37%. Despite some economic growth last year, particularly 6% during periods of stability, the economy lost over 22,000 jobs during the first half of this year. Closures by Israel—both border and internal—are contributing to issues like restricted movement and slower trade, as highlighted in a report. The Palestinian Authority faces challenges with high unemployment among the vulnerable population, particularly those below the poverty line, where some $950 million annually is needed for job creation. The report calls for reform and financial discipline by the Palestinian Authority and emphasizes US support for a peaceful election as Colin Powell visits the West Bank this week.
tinyllama:1.1b: Despite a slight increase in Palestinians' job opportunities in 2003, the economy is performing well below its potential, with an unemployment rate of 25% compared to 10% before the uprising against Israeli occupation four years ago. Young people are particularly affected with 37% out of work compared to 14% in 2000. However, 104,000 new jobs were created during a brief easing of violence and closures this year, but the Palestinian economy lost more than 22,000 jobs last year due to temporary gaps in violence. A close link exists between the number of closure periods - both border closures and internal closures between cities - and Palestinians' economic problems, highlighting the need for reforms and investment-friendly policies. The West Bank's poverty rate has risen to 47%, with nearly half living below the poverty line, and a further 50% considered vulnerable to shocks. Colin Powell, US Secretary of State, visited the West Bank in an attempt to reassure the Palestinians that support for a smooth election will be maintained.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Palestinian economy is in decline, with unemployment levels exceeding 25%. Young people are particularly hard hit, with over 37% out of work compared to less than 14% four years ago. A brief easing of violence and closures has not helped, causing significant job losses and a loss of revenue for the Palestinian economy. The World Bank report blames this on Israeli closures and Intifada, Closure, and Economic Crisis: An Assessment, which attributes closures to both border closures and internal closures between cities. Higher closures restrict movement and trade, slowing down economic activity. According to the report, closures are a significant factor behind today's economic crisis in the West Bank. It suggests that even more would be on the poverty line without an average of $950m per year from international donors. The report also calls for increased investment and reform within the Palestinian Authority to create an investment-friendly climate, which Colin Powell, US Secretary of State, is promoting this week.
phi:2.7b: The Palestinian economy is struggling due to high unemployment rates, particularly among young people, with job losses being recorded even during periods of relative peace. Closures between cities and at borders have been linked to this economic crisis, restricting trade. The World Bank report recommends reviving the reform program and maintaining financial discipline from international donors.
orca-mini:3b: The Palestinian economy is struggling due to closures imposed by Israel, which has led to high unemployment rates among young people and a decline in job creation. Despite some growth in 2003, the report estimates that there was a loss of 22,000 jobs in the first half of this year due to the easing of violence. The report also notes that closures are a key factor behind the current economic crisis and encourages the Palestinian Authority to continue its reform program and maintain financial discipline to create an investment-friendly climate.
hermes3:3b: Palestine Economy Declining: 25% unemployment, 37% youth unemployment; economic growth below potential due to closures limiting trade and movement between cities.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The World Bank report states that the Palestinian economy is performing well below its potential, with 25% unemployment, particularly affecting young people (37%). Though 104,000 new jobs were created in 2003, over 22,000 jobs were lost in the first half of 2004. The closures arranged by Israel are a key factor in the economic crisis, restricting movement and slowing trade. Nearly 47% of Palestinians live below the poverty line and rely on international aid for an average of $950 million per year to create jobs. The report recommends reviving the Palestinian Authority's reform program and maintaining financial discipline to create an investment-friendly climate.
stablelm2:1.6b: The World Bank report reveals that despite temporary job growth in Palestine during a brief easing of violence and closures, the economy remains below its potential with unemployment at 10%, a higher number among young people. However, new jobs were created last year. The economic crisis is attributed to restrictions imposed by Israel through closures, which limit trade and movement of Palestinians. Close to half of Palestinians live in poverty and need job support from international donors. To boost investment conditions, the Palestinian Authority should revive its reform program while maintaining financial discipline to create a more favorable climate for jobs.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
The World Bank report reveals that despite a 2003 job surge, the Palestinian economy is severely underperforming its potential. Unemployment has skyrocketed to 25%, with young people (37%) bearing the brunt of this issue, up from 14% four years ago. Last year, 104,000 new jobs were created during a brief truce, but since June, over 22,000 jobs have been lost. The economic growth rate of 6% in the previous year was largely due to this temporary ceasefire.

The report highlights that Palestinian closures by Israel significantly impact the economy, restricting people's movement and trade. Nearly half of Palestinians (47%) live below the poverty line, making them highly susceptible to economic downturns. Without an annual $950 million from international donors, more would be impoverished. The report advocates for the Palestinian Authority to restore its reform program and uphold fiscal responsibility to foster investment-friendly conditions. Colin Powell, US Secretary of State, recently visited the West Bank to endorse a peaceful January election.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The Palestinian economy is struggling, with unemployment at 25%, up from 10% before the uprising against Israeli occupation. Youth unemployment is particularly high at 37%. A brief easing of violence in 2003 led to 104,000 new jobs and a 6% growth rate, but over 22,000 jobs were lost in early 2004. The World Bank report links economic decline to Israeli-imposed closures restricting movement and trade. Nearly 47% of Palestinians live below the poverty line, with international aid helping to mitigate the crisis. The report urges the Palestinian Authority to implement reforms and maintain financial discipline to attract investment. Meanwhile, US Secretary of State Colin Powell visited the West Bank to support a smooth Palestinian election.
reference: Despite a short-lived increase in Palestinian jobs in 2003, the economy is performing well below its potential, said a World Bank report.According to the report, Intifada, Closures and Palestinian Economic Crisis: An Assessment, there is a close link between the number of closures - both border closures and internal closures between cities - and Palestinian economic problems.However, during the first half of this year, the Palestinian economy lost more than 22,000 jobs.The report said even more would be on the poverty line without an average of $950m a year from international donors, some of which goes towards job creation.Young people are particularly hard hit with 37% out of work, compared with 14% four years ago.But 104,000 new jobs were created last year during a brief easing of violence and closures.
